properties.2405098: Six horses are coughing and appear "cold, dull, and dampish."

properties.stable_name: Ashland Avenue Stables, A. Tuell & Son 1
properties.2405097: Some of the horses are ill.

properties.stable_name: Ashland Avenue Stables, A. Tuell & Son 2
properties.2405091: The two remaining "healthy" horses of the original ten imported horses are moved to this West Side stable to for safe-keeping.

properties.2405103: Maggie, a very valuable mare, dies of complications from the epizootic. Her dissection is scheduled for the following day.
properties.2405104: Maggie's body is necropsied by veterinarians in an attempt to understand the virus.
properties.2405105: Another horse dies of lung inflammation.
properties.2405109: Taking first orders since epizootic started

properties.2405098: All the horses at this coal and wood-dealing barn are sick.

properties.2405099: A mare worth $1,000  dies of lung fever—a complication of the influenza—along with three others.

When interviewed by the Chicago Tribune, Mr. Brady, the propriotor denies the presence of the epizoozy in his barn: "Mr. Brady claimed exemption from the disease yesterday, but in such a manner as to signify that he would not for the life of him admit it even were every horse awaiting internment."

"It seems that Mr. Brady's reluctance to admit the presence of disease is as infectious as the disorder, and has communicated itself to Mr. Bulkely. The former contends that some of those in the latter's stable are sick, and vice versa."

properties.old_street_address: Corner of Cottage Grove Av. and 35th St.

properties.2405100: All sixty horses are sick, along with two mules. One of the mules has a severe case of  influenza.

properties.old_street_address: Northeast Corner of Madison and Market St.
properties.2405100: So many horses are sick, the barn has become "like a hospital."

properties.2405095: Some of the horses begin coughing.
properties.2405102: Frank Parmelee's horses are reportedly improving.
properties.2405105: An "ancient" horse dies of epizoozy complications while the remaining horses "were all feeling remarkably well, eating three meals a day, and acting frisky and in good spirits."

properties.2405100: A large number of the barns 110 horses are now sick.

properties.2405098: In the morning, three horses begin to cough.
Seven horses are coughing and off their feed.

properties.old_street_address: Corner of Monroe and Franklin St.
properties.2405100: The stable has come to resemble a hospital with "all the drivers acting as nurses."
properties.2405102: All sixty horses horses are sick, but with mild cases.

properties.2405098: Twenty horses exhibit symtomps of the influenza.

properties.2405087: Ten horses were imported from Canada and stabled at this barn.
properties.2405089: An old horse imported from Canada—newspapers claim by a black man—shows symptoms of the equine flu: coughing, running at the nose, lethargy.
properties.2405091: Eight of the original ten imported horses are sick with the influenza.

properties.old_street_address: North Clark St., Near Division St.

properties.2405098: All one-hundred horses are coughing and refusing to eat.

properties.2405099: All fifty horses are slightly affected with influenza.

properties.2405095: Symptoms appear in some of the livery horses.
properties.2405098: One-hundred horses are sick and unfit for work.

properties.2405097: The first horses at the street-cleaning barn appear symptomatic.

properties.2405098: 325 horses exhibit "slightly" or "mild" attacks of the epizoozy.
properties.2405103: Some of the horses have returned to work on the street.
properties.2405111: The South Division Car Line is the first street railroad to resume service.

properties.2405099: Thirty-five young horses are sick. The barn owner believes their fresh arrival from the countryside made them especially vulnerable to urban disease.

properties.2405098: All ninety-five horses are coughing but only three are running at the nose.

properties.stable_name: The People's Omnibus Line and Baggage Company 1
properties.2405099: A large number of the horses are suffering from the flu.
properties.2405102: The horses seem to be coughing less.

properties.stable_name: The People's Omnibus and Baggage Company 2

properties.old_street_address: Northeast Corner of Western Av. and W. Washington Blvd.
properties.2405092: Newspapers initially write that the first cases appear here months earlier. Editors blame the two-story stable's terrible ventilation and unsanitary conditions.
properties.2405098: Twenty horses are suffering from the influenza. The newspaper continues its criticism of  barn conditions, writing "All breathe the same tainted atmosphere, and the poor beasts have a less chance of escape on account of the lack of proper ventilation. Altogether the outlook is gloomy for all parties living west of Halsted street, and gloomier as one travels toward the setting sun."
properties.2405100: All 320 horses are sick—some slightly and some seriously.
properties.2405101: More horses are seriously sick. The newspaper describes their rapidly deteriorating appearance: "They have refused their feed for some days, and are being worn to mere skeletons. The bones peer through the skin, and the perpetual coughing seems to shake every joint."
properties.2405103: The sick horses are not improving as expected.

properties.old_street_address: Northeast Corner of Western Av. and W. Washington Blvd.
properties.2405092: Newspapers initially write that the first cases appear here months earlier. Editors blame the two-story stable's terrible ventilation and unsanitary conditions.
properties.2405098: Twenty horses are suffering from the influenza.
